question: Þæs (biscop) #### stan — The bishop’s stone
explanation: Here 'biscop' is in the singular genitive so it takes the 'es' ending

commonMistakes.explanation: While 'biscop' is in the genitive, it is the singular 'biscopes' Biscopa' is the genitive plural

question: Se (þegen) #### ond þa biscops — The thane and the bishops
explanation: Here 'þegen' is the subject so it takes the nominative case

question: Þæs cyninges (þegen) #### — The king’s thanes
explanation: Here 'þegen' is the subject and in the plural, so it takes the 'as' ending of the plural nominative

commonMistakes.explanation: While not apparant in the Old English, þegen is clearly plural in the modern English trans, and so takes the 'as' ending of the nominative plural

question: Þa (cyning) #### ond þa biscopas — The kings and the bishops
explanation: Here 'cyning' is the subject and plural so it takes the 'as' ending of the nominative plural

question: Þara (biscop) #### preostas — The bishops’ priests
explanation: Here 'biscop' is in the possessive plural, since there are multiple priests belong to multiple bishops, so it takes the 'a' ending of the genitive plural

question: In Þæs (cyning) #### tune — In the town of the king
explanation: Here 'cyning' is in the possessive singular so it takes the 'es' ending of the genitive singular

question: Þa Þegnas þara (cyning) #### Ælfred and Æþelred — The thanes of the Kings' Alfred and Ethelred
explanation: Here 'cyning' is in the possessive plural so it takes the 'a' ending of the genitive plural

question: Se (biscop) #### fram þæm tune — The bishop from the town
explanation: Here 'biscop' is the subject and in the singular so it takes no ending, as per the nominative singular

question: Þa Þegnas ond se (cyning) #### — The thane and the king
explanation: Here 'cyning' is subject and in the singular so it takes no ending, as per the nominative singular

question: Fram þæs (þegen) #### tune — From the thane’s town
explanation: Here 'þegen' is in the possessive singular so it takes the 'es' ending of the genitive singular

question: Se cyning ond þa (biscop) #### — The king and the bishops
explanation: Here 'biscop' is part of the subject and plural so it takes the 'as' ending of the nominative plural

question: Þara (þegen) #### menn — The thane’s men
explanation: Here 'þegen' is in the possessive singular so it takes the 'es' ending of the genitive singular

question: Menn fram Þara (þegen) #### tunum — Men from the towns of the thanes
explanation: Here 'þegen' is in the possessive plural as the men are from towns belonging to the thanes, so it takes the 'es' ending of the genitive plural

question: Þa (stan) #### Þæs þegnes tune — The stones from the thane’s town
explanation: Here 'stan' is subject and is plural so it takes the 'as' ending of the nominative plural

question: Se (stan) #### ond se þegen — The stone and the thane
explanation: Here 'stan' is subject and in the singular so it takes no ending, as per the nominative singular

question: Se biscop grete þone (cyning) #### — The bishop greets the king
explanation: Here 'cyning' is directly receiving the action of the verb 'grete', so is in the singular accusative and thus takes no new ending

question: þa biscopas geaf þone (stan) #### to þaem þegne — The bishops gave the stone to the thane
explanation: Here 'stan' is directly receiving the action of the verb 'geaf', so is in the singular accusative and thus takes no new ending

question: Se þegen sloh þone (biscop) #### in tæm tune — the thane slew the bishop in the town
explanation: Here 'biscop' is directly receiving the action of the verb 'sloh', so is in the singular accusative and thus takes no new ending

question: Se cyning ond seo cwen grete þa (biscop) #### — The king and the queen greet the bishops
explanation: Here 'biscop' is directly receiving the action of the verb 'grete' and is also plural, so it is in the plural accusative and thus takes the 'as' ending

question: Se cyning sloh þa (þegen) #### — The king slew the thanes
explanation: Here 'þegen' is directly receiving the action of the verb 'sloh' and is also plural, so it is in the plural accusative and thus takes the 'as' ending

question: Se þegen geaf þa (gar) #### to þaem cyninge — The thane gives the spears to the king
explanation: Here 'gar' is directly receiving the action of the verb 'geaf' and is also plural, so it is in the plural accusative and thus takes the 'as' ending

question: To þæm biscop geaf se cyning þa (beag) #### — The king gave rings to the bishop
explanation: Here 'beag' is directly receiving the action of the verb 'geaf' and is also plural, so it is in the plural accusative and thus takes the 'as' ending

question: To þæm (cyning) #### se biscop geaf beag — To the king, the bishop gives a ring
explanation: Here 'cyning' is not directly receiving the action of the verb 'geaf', so it is in the singular dative and thus takes the 'e' ending.

question: Se þegen ferþ to þæm (biscop) #### mid wordum fram þæm cyning — The thane goes to the bishop with words from the king
explanation: Here 'biscop' is not directly receiving the action of the verb 'ferþ', so it is in the singular dative and thus takes the 'e' ending

question: Se biscop ferde fram þæm (þegen) #### to þæm cyning — The bishop went from the thane to the king
explanation: Here 'þegen' is not directly receiving the action of the verb 'ferde', so it is in the singular dative and thus takes the 'e' ending

question: On þis daeg, Æðelred cyning ferde to þæm (tun) #### mid broðor— On this day, King Ethelred went to the town his brother
explanation: Here 'tun' is not directly receiving the action of the verb 'ferde', so it is in the singular dative and thus takes the 'e' ending

question: Se cyning ferþ to þæm (beorg) #### — The king goes to the mountains
explanation: Here 'beorg' is not directly receiving the action of the verb 'ferþ', so it is in the singular dative and thus takes the 'e' ending

question: Wærferhþ biscop ferde to þæm (biscop) #### in Lundene ond Wiltunscire — Bishop Warfehth went to the bishops of London and Wiltshire
explanation: Here 'biscop' is not directly receiving the action of the verb 'ferde', so it is in the singular dative and thus takes the 'e' ending

question: Se geaf þa garas to þæm (þegen) #### — He gave the spears to the thanes
explanation: Here 'þegen' is not directly receiving the action of the verb 'geaf', so it is in the singular dative and thus takes the 'e' ending

question: þa biscopas came fram þæm (tun) #### hetum Londenum ond Readingum — The bishops came from the towns called London and Reading
explanation: Here 'tun' is not directly receiving the action of the verb 'came', so it is in the singular dative and thus takes the 'e' ending
